results.title: Cyberthon II: The Virtual Transmission [1-hour compiltation]
results.brief_description:
‘Cyberthon II: The Virtual Transmission’ was the second in the series of Cyberthon broadcast events. Set up from TVU’s (Television Unlimited) warehouse and studio in Footscray Victoria, it was once again broadcast live via RMITV’s frequency UHF-31. Unlike the previous Cyberthon and Cyberdelia broadcast events however, Cyberthon II: The Virtual Transmission had expanded in scope afforded by its new venue and increasing popularity of the techno scene.

Adding to the DJ, VJ sets, live performances of electronic music and art, a range of artists also performed live. Artists such as Stelarc performed his Third Arm and Craig Horsham displayed his subversive VHS crash editing of mainstream TV commercials. The Amiga Users Group exhibited a collection of Amiga demos while a diverse range of artists displayed accompanying complex visual effects and art installations.

This one-hour edit was made a year after the 24-hour event occurred.

Visual Artists: Tekno Mandala (Adem Jaffers), Cyber Dada (Dale Nason and Troy Innocent), Future Films (Jeff Jaffers), Don’t Shoot the Messenger (Steve Middleton and Attillio Gangemi), Bureau of Inverse Technology - BIT (Natalie Jeremijenko, Kate Rich and Danny Tigani), Amiga Users Group, Craig Horsham, Force Fed (Stuart McCormick & Michael Brand), Video Graffiti (Andrew Nelson)

Audio Artists: Third Eye ‘Ambi Jam’ (Gus Till, Ollie Olsen, Geoffrey Hales, Simon Polinski), Blast Off Sound System (Jason ‘Rudeboy’ Mac), Foil (Neil Boyack, Andrew Coates, Steve Law, Chris Grierson), 1x4x9 (Braden Schlager & Miles du Heaume), Magnetic Head Circuit (Chubba, Matt Bastard, Peter Randall), Tribal (Duncan Gray, Bruce Yardley & Cam Saunderson), Extroversion (Kate Armstrong), Hardware (Richie ‘Rich’ McNeil), Mystic Force (Russell Hancorne), Poets of the Machine (Koral Island & Stripe)

Performers: Stelarc, Just to fresh, Computer Graphture (Simone Millman and Tanya Hoddinott), Space Between The Gaps (Paul Gafney), Jacinta Le Plastrier, Yoga (Mary Galick, Bronwyn Richie & Paul Gafney), Zenep Jaffers

Cyberthon II: The Virtual Transmission is part of the Cyberthon Archive generously donated to ACMI by Adem Jaffers.

results.title: Cyberthon IV: EPIC Omnicast (Psymmetry in Psyburbia)
results.brief_description:
Cyberthon-IV: EPIC Omnicast (Psymmetry in Psyburbia) was the fourth Cyberthon broadcast event in the Cyberthon series held during the Experimenta festival in 1994. Like the Cyberthon events before it, Cyberthon-IV: EPIC Omnicast was a collaborative, live broadcast featuring artists, performers, DV’s and VJ’s.

This event more than any other Cyberthon broadcast, employed a range of cutting-edge technologies to broaden its reach. Globall participation was fostered via emergent online platforms such as a bulletin board system (BBS), C.U-SeeMe videoconferencing and a multicast backbone (M-Bone) or virtual network. In a Melbourne, if not world first, use of these platforms allowed artists to connect and create with their audience while enthusiasm for experimental electronic music and art saw DV’s and VJ’s mixing audio and images simultaneously while also taking audience requests.

Visual Artists: Tekno Mandala (Adem Jaffers), Cyber Dada (Dale Nason and Troy Innocent), Don’t Shoot the Messenger (Steve Middleton and Attillio Gangemi)

Audio Artists: Voodoo Moon (Ollie Olsen and Arthur Arkin), Zen Paradox (Steve Law), Mystic Force (Russel Hancorne), Psyko Disko (Fred Disco), The Visitor (Andrew Till)

Performers: 3RRR radio host on Tranzmission (Kate Bathgate).

Cyberthon IV: EPIC Omnicast is part of the Cyberthon Archive generously donated to ACMI by Adem Jaffers.

results.title: Cyberthon III: The Underground Connection [event version]
results.brief_description:
‘Cyberthon III: The Underground Connection’ was the third broadcast event in the Cyberthon series, held at TVU’s (Television Unlimited) warehouse and studio in Footscray Victoria. Increasing again in scope and complexity from Cyberthon II, Cyberthon III collaborators invited ten local bands, ten local DJ’s and 3RRR radio hosts Kate Bathgate and Liz Miller to interview artists and participants live at the event. This was in addition to the extensive DV and VJ sets, live artist performances, electronic art and installations on displays. Viewers were also encouraged to interact with participating artists via a bulletin board system (BBS) or fax in a Cyberthon event first.

This is the event version of ‘Cyberthon-III: the underground connection’ to see the [1 hour compilation] see title B2004315

Visual Artists: Tekno Mandala (Adem Jaffers), Cyber Dada (Dale Nason and Troy Innocent), Don’t Shoot the Messenger (Steve Middleton and Attillio Gangemi), Force Fed (Stuart McCormick & Michael Brand), Video Graffiti (Andrew Nelson)

Audio Artists: Darren Jackson (Geeza), Braden Schlager & Miles du Heaume (1x4x9), Soulscraper (Chris Dubrow, Sarah Lord, James Lynch, Elanor Rayner & Jim Shnookal), H2o (Terence Ho ), Vertigo Hypo (Bryan St James & Narelle Wellington), 2120 (Claude Young Jr), Hardware (Richie ‘Rich’ McNeil), Poets of the Machine (Coral and Stripe), The Visitor (Andrew Till), Liz Millar, This Digital Ocean (Liz Millar, Ross Healy & Simon Bowley), Magnetic Head Circuit (Chubba, Matt Bastard, Peter Randall), Blast Off Sound System (Jason ‘Rudeboy’ Mac), Miss Baby Lemonade Lemarr (Andrea), Mish Fingers (Misha Hollenbach), Whip (Kent Morris, Michelle, Mirella, Simon), Geeza (Darren Jackson), Wesley McDonald

Performers: Tranzmission (Kate Bathgate), Liz Millar, Every Picture Tells a Story (Hydi John), Central Station (Joe Polumbo), Yoga (Mary Galick, Eugene-NRG (Paul Gafney) & Bronwyn Richie), Mad Club (Bernie Grogan, Danny Slim, Susan Clinch & Matt the Tree), Taz (Tasilim Emiabata), Star (Raquel Webb), Lizette Broulathaki and Jynell Dolan.

Cyberthon II: The Virtual Transmission is part of the Cyberthon Archive generously donated to ACMI by Adem Jaffers.

results.title: Cyberthon I: For the Mind, Body and Soul
results.brief_description:
‘Cyberthon I: For the Mind Body and Soul’ was the first guerrilla TV broadcast event of its namesake following the success of the Cyberdelia broadcast a year earlier. Conceptualised as a ‘marathon cyber’ event, ‘Cyberthon I: For the Mind Body and Soul’ saw a group of artists broadcast, remix, VJ and DJ mastered footage, experimental Amiga graphics and electronic art alongside performers and a live band at RMITV’s studio in Melbourne. Collaborator and curator to the events, Adem Jaffers said this is where the Cyberthon events really began and over the next four years they would expand in scope to feature over 300 VJ’s, DJ’s, artists, performers and collaborators. 

Visual Artists: Nuero (Adem Jaffers), Cyber Dada (Troy Innocent, Dale Nason and Elena Popa), Future Films (Jeff Jaffers), Interscreen (Kimberley Hughes), Don’t Shoot the Messenger (Steve Middleton and Attillio Gangemi)

Audio Artists: Blast Off Sound System (Jason ‘Rudeboy’ Mac and Terence ‘H20’ Ho), Third Eye (Ollie Olsen), Acid Death Bed (Darren Porter and Paul Wain), Baby Lemonade Lemar (Andrea), Captain ROM

Performers: Taz (Tasilim Emiabata), Star (Raquel Webb), Lizette Broulathaki

‘Cyberthon I: For the Mind Body and Soul’ is part of the Cyberthon Archive generously donated to ACMI by Adem Jaffers.

results.title: [Gadsden Family Home Movie Collection: Reel 21]
results.brief_description:
The Gadsden Company has a long and proud history of manufacture, dating back to its foundation by Jabez Gadsden in 1879. The company pioneered tinplate printing in Australia, and produced the first printed can the country had seen. By 1936 the company had twelve factories spread throughout Australia and New Zealand.

The company’s success allowed two generations of Gadsden family men – Stanley Gadsden and his son Ronald – to pursue their interest in amateur filmmaking (a relatively expensive hobby for the time). The two cameramen captured the family’s children, homes, many of its major events and holidays on film.

A collection of the films made by these Gadsden family photographers has been donated to ACMI by Chris Gadsden (Ronald’s son). The films comprise a fascinating assortment of imagery that provides a window into bygone days and customs.

This reel contains scenes from the family farm, ‘Mooltunya’ in Victoria where we see the flooded creek as well as hay baling and carting hay. The hay-making is a good example of the square smaller bales produced at the time (before large spun round bales) and the manual labour involved in collecting and stacking the bales.

This film was originally made using Super 8mm film.

results.title: [Gadsden Family Home Movie Collection: Reel 3]
results.brief_description:
The Gadsden Company has a long and proud history of manufacture, dating back to its foundation by Jabez Gadsden in 1879. The company pioneered tinplate printing in Australia, and produced the first printed can the country had seen. By 1936 the company had twelve factories spread throughout Australia and New Zealand.

The company’s success allowed two generations of Gadsden family men – Stanley Gadsden and his son Ronald – to pursue their interest in amateur filmmaking (a relatively expensive hobby for the time). The two cameramen captured the family’s children, homes, many of its major events and holidays on film.

A collection of the films made by these Gadsden family photographers has been donated to ACMI by Chris Gadsden (Ronald’s son). The films comprise a fascinating assortment of imagery that provides a window into bygone days and customs.

This reel opens with the title ‘Surfers Paradise May 1975’ written in the sand between waves. The subtitle ‘Passing Parade’ shows the filmmakers intention: life on the beach on the Gold Coast at the time. The reel begins with early morning scenes of both the beach and the duplex holiday house situated right on the sand. We see lots of surfing – board surfing, body surfing and a longboard with paddles. We also see a large jellyfish in the sand, frisbee playing, strolling along the sand in 1970s fashion flares, Gadsdens running in a group along the beach, family members fishing, a commercial fishing boat in the waves, knitting on a towel on sand, sitting on the house balcony with drinks, a barbeque on the rooftop and views along the coastline.

This film was originally made using Super 8mm film.

Selected highlights list:
00:01:56:00 ice cream cart on the beach
00:13:14:00 the filmmaker himself enjoying a XXXX beer while smiling for the camera
00:13:53:00 mid-rise apartment blocks along the coast more sparsely spaced than now

results.title: [Douglas Wilson Home Movies: Reel 5]
results.brief_description:
Douglas Wilson (1919–1980) was an amateur filmmaker whose films are a snapshot of Australia in the 1950s to 1960s. Douglas’s home movies captured aspects of life in Australia’s major cities as well as in regional areas, often with a focus on public areas, transport or infrastructure projects. A collection of his films has been donated to ACMI by a member of Douglas’s family.

The first part of this film briefly shows an outdoor art show before moving on to water ski jumping on the Yarra River – both are part of the ‘Moomba’ celebrations. The second part shows a road trip from Glenroy to Macedon ending at ‘Cameron Lodge’, Macedon all in Victoria.

Good views of the water ski jumping and the crowds watching from the banks. The road trip shows excellent views of small towns such as Keilor and Diggers Rest, vehicles passing on country roads and roadside scenes including telegraph poles.

Extensive views of the gardens of Cameron Lodge in Macedon including the rotunda, lake, stepping stones and family scenes in the garden.

Originally made using 16mm film.

Selected highlights list:
00:00:00:00 outdoor art show
00:00:44:00 Yarra River
00:01:00:00 the ‘Moomba’ festival on the riverbank
00:01:14:00 water skiing
00:02:00:00 water skiing over a jump
00:02:30:00 crowd watching from riverbank
00:03:40:00 title card ‘Glenroy to Macedon 4-3-61’
00:03:47:00 footage of car trip filmed from moving car showing country roads
00:04:38:00 car parked next to Keilor road sign. Good views of cars on road including VW beetle and Holdens, views of telegraph poles
00:05:05:00 road bridge with curved arch
00:05:10:00 ‘Keilor Hotel’ and parked cars, street scenes
00:05:20:00 Diggers Rest town scenes
00:05:40:00 countryside from moving car
00:06:35:00 Jacksons Creek bridge
00:07:28:00 small town with parked Holdens and BP service station
00:07:46:00 title card ‘Cameron Lodge Macedon 4-3-61’
00:07:52:00 views of Cameron Lodge and man walking in gardens
00:08:24:00 views of garden rotunda
00:08:37:00 two women and baby in lodge garden
00:08:40:00 man photographing garden
00:08:47:00 man in rotunda surrounded by lake, crossing stepping stones
00:09:21:00 group walk through lush vegetation including tree ferns
00:09:46:00 walking through lodge garden
00:10:03:00 children playing in rotunda and on stepping stones
00:10:46:00 group of children and adults on lakeside steps
00:11:10:00 title card ‘The End’

results.title: [Douglas Wilson Home Movies: Reel 4]
results.brief_description:
Douglas Wilson (1919–1980) was an amateur filmmaker whose films are a snapshot of Australia in the 1950s to 1960s. Douglas’s home movies captured aspects of life in Australia’s major cities as well as in regional areas, often with a focus on public areas, transport or infrastructure projects. A collection of his films has been donated to ACMI by a member of Douglas’s family.

In this film, we spend time around a bay that is probably Port Phillip in Melbourne. Scenes are filmed on the piers and from the piers, capturing all the activity. There are lovely scenes of yachts sailing, people watching boat races, adults and children fishing and dockside workers undertaking their jobs on the piers.

The film also contains wonderful scenes of the celebration parade for the ‘Centenary of Essendon Municipal Government’ from 1961.

Originally made using 16mm film.

Selected highlights list:
00:00:03:00 a large ship
00:00:20:00 yachts on the bay with a pier in the foreground
00:01:03:00 a large 3-sail yacht tacking in the bay
00:01:19:00 a fishing rod in the foreground
00:01:20:00 children and adults fishing off the pier
00:01:28:00 men working with a tractor and pulley on the pier
00:02:02:00 pulleys being operated to take up large chains and an anchor on a pier
00:02:57:00 closer up to some yachts
00:02:05:00 motor boats on the bay
00:03:50:00 large yacht and passengers close up
00:04:07:00 a military ship
00:04:26:00 yachts racing on the bay
00:04:42:00 an older man, wearing a classic 1940s – 1950s style hat, standing on the pier looking out across the bay
00:05:00:00 a boy wearing rolled up trousers, fishing off the pier and more lovely yachts sailing by before we see a man and another boy who is lying down on the pier alongside his fishing rod
00:05:34:00 a motor boat goes by
00:05:42:00 a young man rowing a small rowboat
00:06:12:00 women wearing wide floral skirts, sitting on beach chairs on the pier, boys fishing and a bicycle
00:06:19:00 a tugboats travels past the pier
00:06:25:00 small cars on the pier
00:06:46:00 a large ship sails into the bay
00:06:55:00 two young boys collect a wicker fishing basket and rods
00:07:24:00 large passenger ship sails close by the end of the pier where some small cars are parked
00:07:40:00 seagulls flying by
00:07:46:00 program for the ‘Centenary of Municipal Government in Essendon 1861 – 1961, official Centennial Celebration program. Saturday December 9’
00:08:00:00 a military band leads a street parade
00:08:20:00 Australian Army members march by
00:08:30:00 various ‘floats’ as well as ‘marching girls’ go by in the celebratory parade
00:08:52:00 the Girl Guides ‘World Wide Friendship’ ‘float’ goes by followed by the Essendon Football Club
00:09:25:00 the Australian Navy contingent goes by, followed by the Victorian Railways ‘float’ showing off a train carriage and a bagpipes band in full regalia
00:10:00:00 – 00:11:15:00 participants in the parade include communities dressed in traditional costumes, the local library, more marching girls, local business and associations and schools, veterans groups and the RSL, a ‘supermarket float’ and a group of horse riders
00:11:33:00 the ‘Bowmen of Essendon’ go by followed by an ‘Australian made’ stilt walker, Christmas ‘floats’ and the Scouts
00:12:05:00 the Australian Air Force, a glimpse of some walking ‘briquettes’ and some girls who might be a netball team or school group
00:12:15:00 young women modelling smart outfits of the day including hats and gloves being driven in a sports car followed by a ‘float’ for a local ‘dance hall’
00:12:45:00 ‘Home Pride Bread horse drawn van goes by with decorations and a young woman ‘baker’, followed by a giant paint tin ‘float’
00:12:53:00 a car and boat accompanied by ‘sea scouts’
00:13:07:00 ‘Essendon Brass Band’ marches by followed by the Ukraine community group in costumes and a local hospital or medical group
00:13:19:00 handmade card for ‘Essendon 1961’

description_for_label:
Douglas Wilson (1919–1980) was an amateur filmmaker whose films are a snapshot of Australia in the 1950s to 1960s. Douglas’s home movies captured aspects of life in Australia’s major cities as well as in regional areas, often with a focus on public areas, transport or infrastructure projects. A collection of his films has been donated to ACMI by a member of Douglas’s family.

In this film, we spend time around a bay that is probably Port Phillip in Melbourne. Scenes are filmed on the piers and from the piers, capturing all the activity. There are lovely scenes of yachts sailing, people watching boat races, adults and children fishing and dockside workers undertaking their jobs on the piers.

The film also contains wonderful scenes of the celebration parade for the ‘Centenary of Essendon Municipal Government’ from 1961.

Originally made using 16mm film.

group.title: [Douglas Wilson Home Movie Collection]
group.material_description: 1 x DVD, 8mm, 16mm home movies and a 35mm film strip.

results.title: [Douglas Wilson Home Movies: Reel 3]
results.brief_description:
Douglas Wilson (1919–1980) was an amateur filmmaker whose films are a snapshot of Australia in the 1950s to 1960s. Douglas’s home movies captured aspects of life in Australia’s major cities as well as in regional areas, often with a focus on public areas, transport or infrastructure projects. A collection of his films has been donated to ACMI by a member of Douglas’s family.

This film titled ‘Sydney’, contains scenes around the Sydney Harbour and the Sydney Harbour Bridge, including the toll station, Circular Quay, the streets and traffic of the CBD and Toronga Park Zoo.

There are scenes are filmed from a high vantage point, probably the Bridge itself and from a boat or ferry on the Harbour.

Originally made using 16mm film.

Selected highlights list:
00:00:05:00 title ‘Sydney’
00:00:45:00 toll stations on the Sydney Harbour Bridge
00:00:57:00 Circular Quay, yachts and scenes around the Harbour from a high vantage point
00:02:11:00 title card ‘Sydney’ followed by scenes of the city
00:03:25:00 Toronga Park and the zoo
00:03:30:00 pelicans on the water followed by koalas, monkeys, seals, penguins, hippopotamus and giraffe standing by a height chart
00:05:29:00 zebras, antlers, flamingoes, tortoises and an emu, lions and tigers, dingoes or dogs of some kind and deer
00:07:48:00 title card ‘Departure from Sydney’ followed by views around Sydney Harbour
